pt: {sc}abuse{/sc} {sc}vituperation{/sc} {sc}invective{/sc} {sc}obloquy{/sc} {sc}billingsgate{/sc} mean vehemently expressed condemnation or disapproval. {sc}abuse{/sc}, the most general term, usually implies the anger of the speaker and stresses the harshness of the language.
{sc}invective{/sc} implies a comparable vehemence but suggests greater verbal and rhetorical skill and may apply to a public denunciation.
{sc}obloquy{/sc} suggests defamation and consequent shame and disgrace.
{sc}billingsgate{/sc} implies practiced fluency and variety of profane or obscene abuse.

pt.t: directed a stream of {it}billingsgate{/it} at the cabdriver

dt: {bc}of, relating to, or characterized by insult or abuse

et: Middle English {it}invectif{/it}, from Middle French, from Latin {it}invectivus{/it}, from {it}invectus{/it}, past participle of {it}invehere{/it}
shortdef: of, relating to, or characterized by insult or abuse
